metadata.description: This data is from "China 1:100,000 land use data".China 1:100,000 land use data was constructed in three years based on Landsat MSS, TM and ETM remote sensing data by using satellite remote sensing as a means to organize remote sensing science and technology teams from 19 institutes affiliated to the Chinese academy of sciences (cas) in the "eighth five-year plan" major application project "national macro survey and dynamic research on remote sensing of resources and environment".The land use data of guizhou province adopts a hierarchical land cover classification system, which divides the country into 6 primary categories (arable land, forest land, grassland, water area, urban and rural areas, industrial and mining areas, residential land and unused land) and 31 secondary categories.It is the most accurate land use data product in China and has played an important role in national land resource survey, hydrological and ecological research.

background: Land-use/cover change has become an event being of paramount importance to the study of global environmental change. Land-cover change is closely related to the terrestrial surface material cycles and life-support processes, i.e., the interaction between biosphere and atmosphere, biodiversity, biogeochemical cycle and sustainable exploitation of resources. The series of scientific study programs, issued and promoted by IGBP and IHDP in 1995, make the study of land-use and land-cover change (LUCC) become one of the hot topics in the global environmental change study. As a developing but booming country, China has formulated a series of policies exerting great influence on the land-use change. In addition, due to varied physical environments and vast land areas, its land-use changes not only influence the social and economic development but also impact the global change accordingly.
research objective: In this paper, the division of dynamic regionalization of land-use change is designed, for the sake of revealing the temporal and spatial features of land-use change and laying the foundation for the study of regional scale land-use changes. The paper exerts an effective effort on the integrated studies of “spatial pattern” and “temporal process” for land-use change to reveal the regional land-use change characteristics on the pattern of dynamic process and dynamic process of pattern.
challenges: It is too early to say that the trend of deforestation has been effectively reversed across China. There also exist conspicuous conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion, as showed in the irrational conversion from arable land to built-up areas.
dataset: The main data sources are Landsat TM digital images (520 scenes in 1995/1996 and 508 scenes in 1999/2000). Apart from that, the CBERS-1 (China-Brazil Earth Resources Satellite 1) data were also used to acquire land-use information for 1999/2000.
findings: There exists conspicuous regional differentiation of land-use change in China, which lays the foundation to draw the dynamic zones. The rapid change of land-use change during 1995—2000 happened in North China, Loess Plateau—agricultural and pasturing interlaced area, Northeast China, southeast coastal region, middle and lower reaches of Yangtze River, eastern coastal region.

background: Land cover plays a significant role in Earth system science, which reflects the influence of human activities and environmental changes. Reliable and up-to-date land cover data are very important for land, ecological and hydrological modelling, carbon and water cycle study as well as global climatic change study. Many land use/cover maps at global, continental, and regional scales have been produced in recent years using remote sensing. These four global land cover maps are all derived from remote sensing data and created for the same fundamental purpose of providing improved land cover information for scientific studies and environmental monitoring, but they are different in mapping methods, data sources, and classification systems.
research objective: The objective of this paper is to evaluate the application of the four popular land cover maps over China land mass. The possibility of developing a new land cover map whose classification is compatible with a well-accepted legend system but whose accuracy is more reliable also motivates this study.
challenges: The four maps used different classification systems, which made the comparison difficult. We conclude that the accuracies of all the datasets cannot meet the requirements of land surface modelling. For the reference data, i.e. the 1:100 000 land cover map, the classification system needs to be transferred to a well-recognized one that has been used commonly in land surface modelling.
methods: We compare and evaluate four land cover datasets over China. So we first aggregated these maps by reclassifying them using a unified legend system. A large-scale, i.e. 1:100 000 land cover map of China was used as the reference data to validate the four maps.
dataset: The datasets include the Version 2 global land cover dataset of IGBP, MODIS land cover map 2001, a global land cover map produced by the University of Maryland, and the land cover map produced by the global land cover for the year 2000 (GLC 2000) project coordinated by the Global Vegetation Monitoring Unit of the European Commission Joint Research Centre. The large-scale (1:100 000) land use map of China in 2000, which was produced by Chinese Academy of Science to meet large-scale resource survey and land use mapping, was used as truth to validate the four land cover maps over China.
findings: The results show that the GLC2000 land cover map represents the highest accuracy. The MODIS land cover map ranks second for type area consistency and third for sub-fraction overall accuracy compared with reference data. The IGBP land cover map has good labelling accuracy, although it has a local labelling error and third consistency for type area. The labelling accuracy and type area consistency for the reference data of UMd land cover map is low.

Definition.Question: What is the concept of 'land-use/cover change' in the context of global environmental change studies?
Definition.Answer: Land-use/cover change refers to the alterations in the terrestrial surface material cycles and life-support processes, which include interactions between the biosphere and atmosphere, biodiversity, biogeochemical cycles, and the sustainable exploitation of resources. It is a critical area of study within global environmental change, particularly given its influence on social and economic development and its larger impact on global change.

Definition.Question: What does 'classification system' mean in the context of land cover mapping and its challenges?
Definition.Answer: In land cover mapping, a 'classification system' is a structured way of categorizing land cover types based on certain criteria. The challenge with classification systems arises when different datasets use varied systems, making comparisons difficult. A unified classification system is necessary for consistent evaluation and to meet requirements for applications like land surface modeling.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using Landsat TM and CBERS-1 for land-use information in the late 1990s compare in terms of effectiveness and challenges?
Comparison.Answer: The use of Landsat TM digital images and CBERS-1 data for land-use information in the late 1990s reflects a combination of satellite remote sensing technologies. The challenges include ensuring data consistency and the potential for classification errors when integrating different sensors. While Landsat TM was widely used for its temporal consistency, CBERS-1 provided complementary data, potentially broadening the spatial coverage. However, both methods faced challenges with classification system compatibility and accuracy for land surface modeling.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences and similarities in the classification systems used by the IGBP global land cover dataset and the large-scale 1:100,000 land use map of China in 2000?
Comparison.Answer: The IGBP global land cover dataset and the large-scale 1:100,000 land use map of China in 2000 both aim to provide comprehensive land cover information, but they differ in their classification systems. The IGBP dataset uses a global classification approach suitable for international comparisons, while the 1:100,000 map is tailored for China's specific resource survey needs, resulting in potentially higher local accuracy. However, for land surface modeling, a unified classification system is necessary to ensure compatibility and reliability across different datasets.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the methods of aggregating and reclassifying land cover maps contribute to their evaluation and comparison over China's land mass?
Comparison.Answer: Aggregating and reclassifying land cover maps is crucial for evaluating and comparing them by creating a unified legend system, which allows for consistent analysis across different datasets. This methodological approach enables the identification of strengths and weaknesses in type area consistency and labelling accuracy. It facilitates direct comparisons with reference data like the 1:100,000 land cover map of China, highlighting issues such as local labelling errors and the need for improved classification systems for accurate land surface modeling.

Interpretation.Question: What implications do the use of Landsat TM digital images and CBERS-1 data have for understanding regional variations in land-use changes over time?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of Landsat TM digital images and CBERS-1 data allows researchers to analyze regional variations in land-use changes by providing detailed temporal and spatial data. This data helps identify dynamic processes and patterns of land-use change, revealing regional characteristics and facilitating the study of land-use dynamics on a broad scale.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in creating accurate land cover maps using remote sensing data in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in creating accurate land cover maps using remote sensing data arise from the use of different classification systems across datasets, which complicates comparison and integration. Furthermore, the accuracies of existing datasets often do not meet the requirements for land surface modeling, indicating a need for standardized classification systems that are widely recognized.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might there be significant regional differentiation in land-use change across China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Significant regional differentiation in land-use change across China can be attributed to the country's varied physical environments and vast land areas. Additionally, rapid changes in land use during specific periods, influenced by socio-economic development and environmental policies, contribute to these regional variations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using a layered land cover classification system in the context of land-use data collection for regional studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of a layered land cover classification system allows for detailed categorization, which can enhance the accuracy of land-use data. This can significantly aid regional studies by providing granular insights into land-use patterns, facilitating better analysis of spatial and temporal changes, and supporting targeted policy-making and resource management.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why might it be important to evaluate and compare multiple land cover datasets over a large geographic area like China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Evaluating and comparing multiple land cover datasets over China is crucial to understand their relative accuracies and applicability. This process allows for the identification of the most accurate datasets for scientific studies and environmental monitoring, as well as the potential creation of a unified classification system that can enhance land surface modeling.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are classification systems standardized across different land cover maps used in research to ensure compatibility and accuracy in land surface modeling?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Standardizing classification systems involves reclassifying land cover maps using a unified legend system. This approach allows for the aggregation of different maps, such as those from IGBP, MODIS, and GLC 2000, enabling their comparison and validation against a reference dataset, like the large-scale 1:100 000 land cover map of China.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies can be employed to address challenges in land-use data accuracy and classification when using remote sensing data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To address challenges in data accuracy and classification, methodologies include validating remote sensing data with a high-resolution reference dataset, transferring classification systems to well-recognized systems used in land surface modeling, and ensuring the compatibility of different land cover datasets through careful evaluation and reclassification.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the use of satellite remote sensing as a primary method for land use data collection in large-scale environmental research?
Enablement.Answer: The use of satellite remote sensing, particularly Landsat MSS, TM, and ETM data, has enabled large-scale land use data collection. These advancements allow for comprehensive monitoring of land use changes over vast areas, such as China, providing critical data for environmental studies.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of multiple satellite data sources, like Landsat and CBERS-1, enhance the accuracy and reliability of land use datasets?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of multiple satellite data sources, such as Landsat TM and CBERS-1, enhances the accuracy and reliability of land use datasets by offering diverse perspectives and data points. This allows for a more detailed and comprehensive understanding of land use changes over time.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do classification systems impact the effectiveness of land cover datasets in supporting land surface modeling?
Enablement.Answer: Classification systems significantly impact the effectiveness of land cover datasets in land surface modeling. Different classification systems can make dataset comparison difficult and affect the accuracy needed for modeling. A unified, well-recognized classification system can facilitate more accurate land surface modeling and enhance dataset utility.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset on land-use change not meet the accuracy requirements for land surface modeling?
Expectation.Answer: The accuracies of the datasets may not meet the requirements of land surface modeling due to differences in classification systems, which make comparison difficult, and the need for the reference classification system to be transferred to a well-recognized one used in land surface modeling.

Expectation.Question: What challenges could arise when comparing different land cover datasets over a large geographic area?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in comparing different land cover datasets may include variations in classification systems among the datasets, which complicate direct comparisons and may result in discrepancies in accuracy and reliability for scientific studies.

Judgmental.Question: How effective are satellite remote sensing techniques, such as those used in Landsat MSS, TM, and ETM, in capturing the nuances of land-use changes in complex environments like China's varied landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: Satellite remote sensing techniques, using data from Landsat MSS, TM, and ETM, have proven effective in capturing land-use changes by providing detailed and high-resolution imagery that is essential for understanding complex landscapes. These methods facilitate the classification of land into various categories, which is crucial for analyzing changes over time and space. The technique's effectiveness is evident in its application in national land resource surveys and environmental studies.

Judgmental.Question: In evaluating land cover datasets, what are the key challenges researchers face, particularly regarding classification systems and accuracy requirements?
Judgmental.Answer: Key challenges in evaluating land cover datasets include the use of different classification systems, which complicates comparisons across datasets. Additionally, meeting the accuracy requirements necessary for land surface modeling is difficult, as many datasets, despite their detail, do not meet these standards. This necessitates reclassification and validation against reference data to ensure reliability and consistency in land cover data.

Judgmental.Question: Considering the diversity of datasets like GLC 2000 and MODIS, how might researchers approach improving classification accuracy and consistency for land-use maps over large areas like China?
Judgmental.Answer: Researchers can improve classification accuracy and consistency by developing a unified legend system that aligns with well-accepted classification standards used in land surface modeling. By aggregating and reclassifying existing maps, and validating them against large-scale reference data, such as the 1:100,000 land use map of China, researchers can enhance the datasets' reliability, facilitating better integration into scientific and environmental monitoring applications.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges faced in ensuring the accuracy of land cover maps used for environmental studies.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include the use of different classification systems across various maps, which makes comparisons difficult. There is a need to align classification systems to a well-recognized standard for land surface modeling to meet accuracy requirements.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand why land-use changes are considered significant for global environmental studies.
Assertion.Answer: Land-use changes are significant because they influence the terrestrial surface material cycles and life-support processes, affecting interactions between the biosphere and atmosphere, biodiversity, and biogeochemical cycles. These changes impact social, economic development, and global environmental change.
